results.text: Journal of Music Therapy, XLII (3), 2005, 216-239 �9 2005 by the American Music Therapy Association Personality and Music Preferences: The Influence of Personality Traits on Preferences Regarding Musical Elements Malgorzata Kopacz, PhD, MT-BC Opole University Opole, Poland The purpose of this scientific study was to determine how personafity traits, as classified by Cattell, influence preferences regarding musical elements. The subject group consisted of 145 students, male and female, chosen at random from dif-ferent Polish universities. For the purpose of determining their personafity traits the participants completed the 16PF Questionnaire (Cattell, Saunders, & Stice, 1957; Russel & Karol, 1993), in its Polish adaptation by Choynowski (Nowakowska, 1970). The participants' musical preferences were determined by their completing a Questionnaire of Mu-sical Preferences (specifically created for the purposes of this research), in which respondents indicated their favorite piece of music. Next, on the basis of the Questionnaire of Mu-sical Preferences, a list of the works of music chosen by the participants was compiled. All pieces were collected on CDs and analyzed to separate out their basic musical elements. The statistical analysis shows that some personafity traits: Liveliness (Factor F), Social Boldness (Factor H), Vigilance (Factor L), Openness to Change (Factor Q1), Extraversion (a general factor) have an influence on preferences regarding musical elements. Important in the subjects' musical prefer-ences were found to be those musical elements having stim-ulative value and the ability to regulate the need for stimula-tion. These are: tempo, rhythm in relation to metrical basis, number of melodic themes, sound voluminosity, and meter. Malgorzata Kopacz, PhD, MT-BC, is Assistant Professor at The Department of Psy-chology, Opole University. Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 217 Vol. XLII, No. 3, Fall2005 The subject of musical preferences is an unusually important one, both with regard to music therapy and for all methods and techniques in which music is employed. A knowledge of musical preferences is enormously significant in the selection of music for therapeutic work. Many studies show that music preferred by the client is comparable in its effectiveness to that chosen by the thera-pist, with regard to reduction of anxiety (Iwanaga & Moroki, 1999; Thaut & Davis, 1999). For the purposes for this article, musical preferences have been defined as "the act of choosing, esteeming, or giving advantage to one thing over another through a verbal statement, rating scale re-sponse, or choice made from two or more alternatives" (Kuhn, 1980). In the literature on the subject, many factors can be identi-fied as having considerable impact on musical preferences. These include personality traits (Burt, 1939; Daoussis & McKelvie, 1986; Klimas-Kuchtowa, 2000; McCown, Keiser, Mulhearn, & Williamson, 1997; Rawlings, Hodge, Sherr, & Dempsey, 1995). Research into personality-dependent musical preferences has quite a long history. Most of it is associated with Eysenck's personality di-mensions: extraversion, neuroticism and psychoticism (Eysenck, 1958). Extraverts prefer usually homogenous, lively, emotional vigor-ous, sensual music, while introverts prefer intellectual, mystical, deep, introspective and restrained music (Burt, 1939; Klimas-Kuchtowa, 2000). In turn, psychoticism is significantly correlated with prefer-ences for musical complexity. People with high levels of psychoticism prefer more complicated and complex pieces than people with low levels of psychoticism (Rawlings et al., 1995). Interesting findings emerged from research conducted by McCown et al. (1997). From this, it emerges that traits such as extraversion and psychoticism are positively correlated with preferences for works of music played back with amplified bass. Other research, by Furnham, Trew, and Sneade (1999), shows that music as a means of stimulation may aid cognitive activity in extraverts and suppress cognitive activity among introverts. With the above consideration in mind, it was decided to check what relationships exist between personality traits, as classified by Cattell, and musical preferences. The choice of Cattell's theory was dictated by the fact that Cattell describes personality structure in a detailed way, separating out 16 factors. This is in accordance with the suggestions of Furman and Avison (1997), who claim that nar-rower dimensions of personality may be more useful in the study of Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 218 Journal of Music Therapy artistic preferences. It is probable that the use of narrow dimensions of personality allows a more precise description of the rela-tionship between personality traits and the specific musical ele-ments that make up the works of music chosen by participants. The research into musical preferences was conducted based on the latest advances in cognitive psychology in the field of music perception (Sloboda, 1999). Currently, it is emphasized that per-ception of music is based on the perception of musical elements, and takes place in accordance with set rules (similarly to the per-ception of speech according to psycholinguistic theory). To under-stand a work of music, it must first be analyzed structurally, in ac-cordance with the rules of representation theory, common to composers, listeners and performers. In consequence, in this re-search each piece of music (as chosen by the participants) was an-alyzed, for the purpose of classifying its primary musical elements. This study is an attempt to answer two questions. First, whether people with certain personality traits prefer the certain musical ele-ments in works of music and, second, which personality" traits have a particular influence on preferences regarding musical elements. On the basis of the considerations set out above, it may be hypothesized that some personality traits described by Cattell Warmth (A), Liveli-ness (F), Social Boldness (H), Self-Reliance (Q2), Abstractedness (M), Openness to Change (Q1), Vigilance (L), comprising the Gen-eral Extraversion Factor' will determine preferences regarding musi-cal elements. The following hypothesizes were therefore formulated: HI: Factor A has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements H2: Factor F has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements H3: Factor H has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements H4: Factor Q2 has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements H5: Factor M has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements l In the Polish adaptation the 16PF Questionnaire, 3 additional factors comprising Extraversion have been introduced: M-, QI-, L-. Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 219 Vol. XLII, No. 3, Fall 2005 H6: Factor Q1 has an effect oll preferences regarding certain musical elements H7: Factor L has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements. Method Participants Randomly chosen students (N--- 145) in higher education in Poland participated in this study. The age range was 19-26, and the sample consisted of 85 women and 60 men. The participants de-clared that while they enjoyed listening to the music, they did not have a professional music education. The emphasis during the se-lection on the level of musical education was designed to create a group that was homogenous in terms of overall music apprecia-tion, that is, to eliminate the analytical music-listening abilities characteristic of professionally educated musicians. The partici-pants also declared that they did not identify u4th any subculture group. This is significant because music in such groups has a spe-cific role, which is outside the scope of this study. Material The 16 PF Questionnaire (Cattell et al., 1957; Russel & Karol, 1993) in the Polish adaptation by Choynowski (Nowakowska, 1970) was used in this research, as well as the Questionnaire of Musical Pref-erences (created by the author for the purposes of this research). The Questionnaire of Musical Preferences consists of instructions and a part in which the respondent writes in information regarding their favorite piece of music: title, performer, composer (in the case of classical music) and title of the recording where the work is to be found. Musical analysis employed in musicology was also used in the re-search. The musical analysis involved the isolation of basic ele-ments contained in the musical composition (Chominski & Wilkowska-Chominska, 1983; Sadie, 1980). Before beginning test-ing, nine musical elements were selected. Each of the elements was divided into several categories which, in the opinion of the author, enable an objective description of the piece of music. In the research undertaken, the musical analysis involved listen-ing to each piece chosen by the participants and assigning to it a Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 220 Journal of Music Therapy specific category for each musical element. For the purposes of the research, the following elements were isolated: 1. Tempo---measured using a metronome; howevex, in descriptions and in the interpretation of data, words describing tempo have been used, based on metronome speed: (a) quarter note < 40 (adagio), (b) quarter note = 40-60 (andante), (c) quarter note = 61-80 (moderato), (d) quarter note = 81-100 (allegretto), (e) quarter note = 101-120 (allegro), (f) quarter note > 120 (presto); 2. Changes in Tempo (acceleration or deceleration within single phrases, musical sentences or parts): (a) lack of tempo changes, (b) moderate changes (changes within a portion of the piece), (c) frequent changes (changes within musical sentences and phrases); 3. Rhythm in relation to metrical basis: (a) majority of rhythm val-ues longer than metrical basis (e.g., half note in 4/4 time), (b) majority of values similar to metrical basis (e.g., quarter note in 4/4 time), (c) majority of rhythm values shorter than metrical basis (e.g., eighth note and sixteenth note in the 4/4 time); 4. Number of Melodic Themes: (a) small--number and distribu-tion of melodic themes similar to the layout of the main part of the work (e.g., verses, refrains), (b) large--a variety of melodic themes within the work of music; 5. Sound Voluminosity (i.e., variety of instruments): (a) low--only one or two instruments, except in the case of piano, organ, gui-tar and electronic instruments (if used with a wide sound spec-trum in the piece), (b) moderate--ranging from three instru-ments playing simultaneously up to the sound spectrum characteristic of a chamber orchestra, (c) high--instruments characteristic of a symphony orchestra, the piano or guitar in full voice, and also combinations of electrical or electronic in-struments, as well as loud percussion; 6. Meter: (a) duple and quadruple rhythm, (b) triple rhythm, (d) asymmetric rhythm (e.g., 5/4, 7/4), (e) hybrid rhythm, (e) free time (lack of beat) ; 7. Sound Dynamics over the course of the piece2: (a) no changes, 2 It was not possible to objectively establish the volume level for each piece by indi-vidual participant, since the participants filled in only data associated with their fa-vorite work of music. Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 221 Vol. XLII, No. 3, Fall 2005 (b) one volume level in some parts of the piece, with sudden changes of volume between parts, (c) gradual increases or de-creases in volume during the piece; 8. Melodics, in the sense of a set selection of notes, based on the total sequence adopted, that is, scale: (a) pre-modal, (b) modal, (c) chromatic major, (d) chromatic minor, (e) chromatic major and minor, (f) whole-tone scale, (g) serial dodecaphonic struc-tures; 9. Leading Instrument Timbre (this category includes those in-struments, together with the human voice, that were actually se-lected by respondents, with the result that this category arose fol-lowing the collection and analysis of the pieces)~: (a) soprano, (b) mezzo-soprano, (c) alto, (d) tenor, (e) baritone, (f) bass, (g) soprano and tenor, (h) soprano and baritone, (i) choir, (l) vio-lin, (k) piano, (1) saxophone, (m) electric guitar, (n) synthe-sizer, (o) others. As a result of this analysis, each work of music was characterized in terms of the nine element set: Tempo, Changes in Tempo, Rhythm, Number of Melodic Themes, Sound Voluminosity, Meter, Sound Dynamics, Melodics, Leading Instrument Timbre. Procedure This research was conducted over a one-month period at the fol-lowing Polish universities: Wroclaw University, Wroclaw Technical University, Wroclaw School of Economics, Rzeszow Technical Uni-versity. The testing was undertaken in the lecture rooms of the above academic institutions, during morning hours, by daylight. Due to the time of year (fall) and the necessity of maintaining low noise levels in the rooms, all windows were closed during testing. The lectureroom walls were white in color. Testing was carried out in groups, with each group numbering about 20 people. Those who agreed to take part in this research were informed of its pur-pose and its progress. They completed the 16 PF Questionnaire and the Questionnaire of MusicaI Preferences. After collecting the completed questionnaires, analysis of these findings was begun. Using the 16 PF Questionnaire, the personality SCreating this category before musical analysis was impossible, due to the massive number of instruments appearing in the musical literature. Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 222 Journal of Music Therapy traits of the participants were determined. Next, on the basis of the Questionnaire of Musical Preferences, a complete list of works of music, consisting of 117 pieces, was compiled (a listing of the pieces is shown in Appendix 1). The pieces, collected on CDs, were musi-cally analyzed, with each piece being described in terms of the nine-element set. Results A number of statistical methods were used in the verification of the hypotheses. For the determination of correlations between per-sonality traits and musical elements, two correlation coefficients were used. These are: Spearman's 7;, for ordinal variables (for mu-sic elements: Tempo, Changes in Tempo, Rhythm, Number of Melodic Themes, Sound Voluminosity) and Cramer's Vfor nomi-nal variables (for music elements: Meter, Sound Dynamics, Melod-ics, Leading Instrument Timbre). Next, F-test analysis of analysis of variance (ANOVA) was applied. The cz significance level was set at p < .05. The results of the statistical analysis are shown in Table 1. The discussion of the results is presented in a uniform format. First, the results for correlation coefficients are presented, next the variance analysis results. For those personality traits achieving sta-tistically significant values in the variance analysis, compilations of mean values are shown in chart form. The greatest number of relationships to musical elements was shown by Factor H. It achieved correlations with three elements: Tempo, Number of Melodic Themes and Meter. The q values in the case of Tempo and Number of Melodic Themes are positive, meaning that together with an increase in Factor H, preferences for musical pieces with faster tempo and a greater number of melodic themes increase. In the analysis of variance, Factor H also had relationships with three musical elements: Tempo, Number of Melodic Themes and Meter. In analyzing the compilation of mean Factor-H values for the element Tempo (see Figure 1), it is notice-able that people with the highest mean H are those choosing fast tempos in pieces of music. Further down the sequence with regard to mean H values are those choosing: Very Fast, Moderately Fast, Moderately Slow, Very Slow and Slow Tempos. The analysis of mean values for Factor F (see Figure 4) and Factor Q1 (see Figure 5) indicates that people characterized by a higher mean F and Q1 choose pieces with a high number of melodic themes, while conversely people with lower mean F and Q1 choose pieces with a low number of melodic themes. relations.sentence: Journal of Music Therapy, XLII (3), 2005, 216-239  9 2005 by the American Music Therapy Association Personality and Music Preferences: The Influence of Personality Traits on Preferences Regarding Musical Elements Malgorzata Kopacz, PhD, MT-BC Opole University Opole, Poland The purpose of this scientific study was to determine how personafity traits, as classified by Cattell, influence preferences regarding musical elements.
Malgorzata Kopacz, PhD, MT-BC, is Assistant Professor at The Department of Psy-chology, Opole University.

Many studies show that music preferred by the client is comparable in its effectiveness to that chosen by the thera-pist, with regard to reduction of anxiety (Iwanaga & Moroki, 1999; Thaut & Davis, 1999).
These include personality traits (Burt, 1939; Daoussis & McKelvie, 1986; Klimas-Kuchtowa, 2000; McCown, Keiser, Mulhearn, & Williamson, 1997; Rawlings, Hodge, Sherr, & Dempsey, 1995).
These include personality traits (Burt, 1939; Daoussis & McKelvie, 1986; Klimas-Kuchtowa, 2000; McCown, Keiser, Mulhearn, & Williamson, 1997; Rawlings, Hodge, Sherr, & Dempsey, 1995).
Other research, by Furnham, Trew, and Sneade (1999), shows that music as a means of stimulation may aid cognitive activity in extraverts and suppress cognitive activity among introverts.

This is in accordance with the suggestions of Furman and Avison (1997), who claim that nar-rower dimensions of personality may be more useful in the study of Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 218 Journal of Music Therapy artistic preferences.

On the basis of the considerations set out above, it may be hypothesized that some personality traits described by Cattell Warmth (A), Liveli-ness (F), Social Boldness (H), Self-Reliance (Q2), Abstractedness (M), Openness to Change (Q1), Vigilance (L), comprising the Gen-eral Extraversion Factor' will determine preferences regarding musi-cal elements.
Method Participants Randomly chosen students (N--- 145) in higher education in Poland participated in this study.

Material The 16 PF Questionnaire (Cattell et al., 1957; Russel & Karol, 1993) in the Polish adaptation by Choynowski (Nowakowska, 1970) was used in this research, as well as the Questionnaire of Musical Pref-erences (created by the author for the purposes of this research).

The Questionnaire of Musical Preferences consists of instructions and a part in which the respondent writes in information regarding their favorite piece of music: title, performer, composer (in the case of classical music) and title of the recording where the work is to be found.

The Questionnaire of Musical Preferences consists of instructions and a part in which the respondent writes in information regarding their favorite piece of music: title, performer, composer (in the case of classical music) and title of the recording where the work is to be found.

The testing was undertaken in the lecture rooms of the above academic institutions, during morning hours, by daylight.
Testing was carried out in groups, with each group numbering about 20 people.
Testing was carried out in groups, with each group numbering about 20 people.

Dividing absolute tempo into 3 groups: Fast Tempos (quarter note > 101), Moderate Tempos (quarter note = 61-100), Slow Tempos (quarter note < 60), it is noticeable that people choosing Fast Tempos are characterized Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 40 223 VOI.

In the case of the element Number of Melodic Themes, people characterized by high mean H values choose pieces with a high number of melodic themes.

For the purpose of determining their personafity traits the participants completed the 16PF Questionnaire (Cattell, Saunders, & Stice, 1957; Russel & Karol, 1993), in its Polish adaptation by Choynowski (Nowakowska, 1970).
People with lower mean H values choose pieces with a low number of melodic themes (see Figure 2).

results.text: GLYPH<g1008>GLYPH<g1008>GLYPH<g3> GLYPH<g3> GLYPH<g3> Several studies have looked at how people’s music preference and personality are related to the sub-culture surrounding the music they like (Arnett, 1991; North & Hargreaves, 1999). Future research focusing on these different sub-cultures may lead to pertinent discoveries about how music affects individuals not only as a leisure activity but as a part of their identity and how it affects them socially. Finally, it may be useful to look at not only what music people listen to, and the different ways in which they listen to music, but finding out the reason why people enjoy listening to different types of music could also be invaluable. Practical and theoretical Implications There have been numerous studies showing that much psychological information gained by exploring a music preference. However, although the area of music in Psychology is growing, it is still chronically understudied. Seeing as how most people rate music very highly in terms of what is important to them and they believe it is something that makes up their individuality (Rentfrow & Gosling, 2003) and can provide valuable insights into their personality, studies such as the present one are very useful in broadening the previous literature. Music has not only been shown to be an integral part of a person’s identity but also a big part in their social life as music is played in so many social situations and oftentimes people are part of subcultures that have to do with their music preference. Understanding a person’s music preference on the sub-culture they are part of because of music has many practical applications for counsellors and Psychologists as it can help them gain greater insights to the personalities and social identities of their patients. Music has also been shown to have a number of useful psychological applications such as enhancing mood, emotional regulation, evoking memories and even helping people to communicate who could not do so otherwise (Barret et al, 2010; Hunter et al, 2011; Zenter et al, 2008). GLYPH<g1008>GLYPH<g1009>GLYPH<g3> GLYPH<g3> GLYPH<g3> Studies like the present one, which help to expand on previous research by showing that there is a definite correlation between the type of music a person listens to and their personality type could also be of use to the music industry as they could possibly have a more personalised approach when marketing music to people as they could use ads that appeal to certain personality types rather than basing their marketing purely on age and demographics. For example if they knew that people who were extraverts were more likely to listen to energetic and complex music, they could advertise this type of music in mediums that extraverts are more likely to come in contact with such as music festivals or large social events. Whereas if they knew that people who were open to experience were more likely to enjoy complex and reflective music, they could market it to them in a way that emphasizes how new and exciting the new music they were pushing were. This study would also be of use to social psychologists as music is clearly a social phenomenon and can be used as a pathway into a person’s social attitudes and beliefs identity (North & Hargreaves, 1999 ). People tend to listen to music which is in accordance to their own views and beliefs and so knowing a person’s music preferences could be useful in gaining awareness of their lifestyle patters, personal tendencies’ and social identity. Many researchers believe that one of the functions of music is the consolidation of identity (Chamorro-Premuzic & Furnham, 2007). This study would also be relevant to counsellor’s, teachers, parents and educational Psychologists because past research has indicated that certain types of music such as heavy metal music are linked with anti-social behaviour, anger and emotional problems(Epstein, Pratto, Skipper, 1998; et al Arnett, 1991) GLYPH<g1008>GLYPH<g1010>GLYPH<g3> GLYPH<g3> GLYPH<g3> They also found that a preference for heavy music in adolescence was correlated with having an unhappy family life. Adolescents who prefer lighter music were more likely to be socially awkward and have problems building social relationships. Thus it may be a warning signal if a child or adolescent is listening to heavy metal or hip hop that they may have some family or emotional issues worth exploring, which could help them with their development. It might therefore be useful to learn a person’s music preference which could help to give a sense of their personality profile and understand what issues they might be facing (Schwartz & Fouts, 2003 ). Finally, it is useful to learn a person’s music preference as it is another tool that Psychologists can use to unlock their patients emotional cognitive needs. Conclusion This study was successful in elaborating further an area of study which is still in the early stages of development. There was a relationship found between Openness to experience and the reflective/complex, intense and rebellious and energetic and rhythmic music dimensions. There was also a relationship found between extraversion and the energetic and rhythmic music dimension. Additionally, the over 30 age group displayed a correlation between the conscientiousness personality trait and the music dimensions intense/rebellious and energetic and rhythmic. These findings suggest that there is a definite relationship between music preference and personality, but the picture is far from complete and in order to truly uncover this relationship further intensive research is required. results.text: Journal of Music Therapy, XLII (3), 2005, 216-239 �9 2005 by the American Music Therapy Association Personality and Music Preferences: The Influence of Personality Traits on Preferences Regarding Musical Elements Malgorzata Kopacz, PhD, MT-BC Opole University Opole, Poland The purpose of this scientific study was to determine how personafity traits, as classified by Cattell, influence preferences regarding musical elements. The subject group consisted of 145 students, male and female, chosen at random from dif-ferent Polish universities. For the purpose of determining their personafity traits the participants completed the 16PF Questionnaire (Cattell, Saunders, & Stice, 1957; Russel & Karol, 1993), in its Polish adaptation by Choynowski (Nowakowska, 1970). The participants' musical preferences were determined by their completing a Questionnaire of Mu-sical Preferences (specifically created for the purposes of this research), in which respondents indicated their favorite piece of music. Next, on the basis of the Questionnaire of Mu-sical Preferences, a list of the works of music chosen by the participants was compiled. All pieces were collected on CDs and analyzed to separate out their basic musical elements. The statistical analysis shows that some personafity traits: Liveliness (Factor F), Social Boldness (Factor H), Vigilance (Factor L), Openness to Change (Factor Q1), Extraversion (a general factor) have an influence on preferences regarding musical elements. Important in the subjects' musical prefer-ences were found to be those musical elements having stim-ulative value and the ability to regulate the need for stimula-tion. These are: tempo, rhythm in relation to metrical basis, number of melodic themes, sound voluminosity, and meter. Malgorzata Kopacz, PhD, MT-BC, is Assistant Professor at The Department of Psy-chology, Opole University. Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 217 Vol. XLII, No. 3, Fall2005 The subject of musical preferences is an unusually important one, both with regard to music therapy and for all methods and techniques in which music is employed. A knowledge of musical preferences is enormously significant in the selection of music for therapeutic work. Many studies show that music preferred by the client is comparable in its effectiveness to that chosen by the thera-pist, with regard to reduction of anxiety (Iwanaga & Moroki, 1999; Thaut & Davis, 1999). For the purposes for this article, musical preferences have been defined as "the act of choosing, esteeming, or giving advantage to one thing over another through a verbal statement, rating scale re-sponse, or choice made from two or more alternatives" (Kuhn, 1980). In the literature on the subject, many factors can be identi-fied as having considerable impact on musical preferences. These include personality traits (Burt, 1939; Daoussis & McKelvie, 1986; Klimas-Kuchtowa, 2000; McCown, Keiser, Mulhearn, & Williamson, 1997; Rawlings, Hodge, Sherr, & Dempsey, 1995). Research into personality-dependent musical preferences has quite a long history. Most of it is associated with Eysenck's personality di-mensions: extraversion, neuroticism and psychoticism (Eysenck, 1958). Extraverts prefer usually homogenous, lively, emotional vigor-ous, sensual music, while introverts prefer intellectual, mystical, deep, introspective and restrained music (Burt, 1939; Klimas-Kuchtowa, 2000). In turn, psychoticism is significantly correlated with prefer-ences for musical complexity. People with high levels of psychoticism prefer more complicated and complex pieces than people with low levels of psychoticism (Rawlings et al., 1995). Interesting findings emerged from research conducted by McCown et al. (1997). From this, it emerges that traits such as extraversion and psychoticism are positively correlated with preferences for works of music played back with amplified bass. Other research, by Furnham, Trew, and Sneade (1999), shows that music as a means of stimulation may aid cognitive activity in extraverts and suppress cognitive activity among introverts. With the above consideration in mind, it was decided to check what relationships exist between personality traits, as classified by Cattell, and musical preferences. The choice of Cattell's theory was dictated by the fact that Cattell describes personality structure in a detailed way, separating out 16 factors. This is in accordance with the suggestions of Furman and Avison (1997), who claim that nar-rower dimensions of personality may be more useful in the study of Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 218 Journal of Music Therapy artistic preferences. It is probable that the use of narrow dimensions of personality allows a more precise description of the rela-tionship between personality traits and the specific musical ele-ments that make up the works of music chosen by participants. The research into musical preferences was conducted based on the latest advances in cognitive psychology in the field of music perception (Sloboda, 1999). Currently, it is emphasized that per-ception of music is based on the perception of musical elements, and takes place in accordance with set rules (similarly to the per-ception of speech according to psycholinguistic theory). To under-stand a work of music, it must first be analyzed structurally, in ac-cordance with the rules of representation theory, common to composers, listeners and performers. In consequence, in this re-search each piece of music (as chosen by the participants) was an-alyzed, for the purpose of classifying its primary musical elements. This study is an attempt to answer two questions. First, whether people with certain personality traits prefer the certain musical ele-ments in works of music and, second, which personality" traits have a particular influence on preferences regarding musical elements. On the basis of the considerations set out above, it may be hypothesized that some personality traits described by Cattell Warmth (A), Liveli-ness (F), Social Boldness (H), Self-Reliance (Q2), Abstractedness (M), Openness to Change (Q1), Vigilance (L), comprising the Gen-eral Extraversion Factor' will determine preferences regarding musi-cal elements. The following hypothesizes were therefore formulated: HI: Factor A has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements H2: Factor F has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements H3: Factor H has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements H4: Factor Q2 has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements H5: Factor M has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements l In the Polish adaptation the 16PF Questionnaire, 3 additional factors comprising Extraversion have been introduced: M-, QI-, L-. Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 219 Vol. XLII, No. 3, Fall 2005 H6: Factor Q1 has an effect oll preferences regarding certain musical elements H7: Factor L has an effect on preferences regarding certain musical elements. Method Participants Randomly chosen students (N--- 145) in higher education in Poland participated in this study. The age range was 19-26, and the sample consisted of 85 women and 60 men. The participants de-clared that while they enjoyed listening to the music, they did not have a professional music education. The emphasis during the se-lection on the level of musical education was designed to create a group that was homogenous in terms of overall music apprecia-tion, that is, to eliminate the analytical music-listening abilities characteristic of professionally educated musicians. The partici-pants also declared that they did not identify u4th any subculture group. This is significant because music in such groups has a spe-cific role, which is outside the scope of this study. Material The 16 PF Questionnaire (Cattell et al., 1957; Russel & Karol, 1993) in the Polish adaptation by Choynowski (Nowakowska, 1970) was used in this research, as well as the Questionnaire of Musical Pref-erences (created by the author for the purposes of this research). The Questionnaire of Musical Preferences consists of instructions and a part in which the respondent writes in information regarding their favorite piece of music: title, performer, composer (in the case of classical music) and title of the recording where the work is to be found. Musical analysis employed in musicology was also used in the re-search. The musical analysis involved the isolation of basic ele-ments contained in the musical composition (Chominski & Wilkowska-Chominska, 1983; Sadie, 1980). Before beginning test-ing, nine musical elements were selected. Each of the elements was divided into several categories which, in the opinion of the author, enable an objective description of the piece of music. In the research undertaken, the musical analysis involved listen-ing to each piece chosen by the participants and assigning to it a Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 220 Journal of Music Therapy specific category for each musical element. For the purposes of the research, the following elements were isolated: 1. Tempo---measured using a metronome; howevex, in descriptions and in the interpretation of data, words describing tempo have been used, based on metronome speed: (a) quarter note < 40 (adagio), (b) quarter note = 40-60 (andante), (c) quarter note = 61-80 (moderato), (d) quarter note = 81-100 (allegretto), (e) quarter note = 101-120 (allegro), (f) quarter note > 120 (presto); 2. Changes in Tempo (acceleration or deceleration within single phrases, musical sentences or parts): (a) lack of tempo changes, (b) moderate changes (changes within a portion of the piece), (c) frequent changes (changes within musical sentences and phrases); 3. Rhythm in relation to metrical basis: (a) majority of rhythm val-ues longer than metrical basis (e.g., half note in 4/4 time), (b) majority of values similar to metrical basis (e.g., quarter note in 4/4 time), (c) majority of rhythm values shorter than metrical basis (e.g., eighth note and sixteenth note in the 4/4 time); 4. Number of Melodic Themes: (a) small--number and distribu-tion of melodic themes similar to the layout of the main part of the work (e.g., verses, refrains), (b) large--a variety of melodic themes within the work of music; 5. Sound Voluminosity (i.e., variety of instruments): (a) low--only one or two instruments, except in the case of piano, organ, gui-tar and electronic instruments (if used with a wide sound spec-trum in the piece), (b) moderate--ranging from three instru-ments playing simultaneously up to the sound spectrum characteristic of a chamber orchestra, (c) high--instruments characteristic of a symphony orchestra, the piano or guitar in full voice, and also combinations of electrical or electronic in-struments, as well as loud percussion; 6. Meter: (a) duple and quadruple rhythm, (b) triple rhythm, (d) asymmetric rhythm (e.g., 5/4, 7/4), (e) hybrid rhythm, (e) free time (lack of beat) ; 7. Sound Dynamics over the course of the piece2: (a) no changes, 2 It was not possible to objectively establish the volume level for each piece by indi-vidual participant, since the participants filled in only data associated with their fa-vorite work of music. Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 221 Vol. XLII, No. 3, Fall 2005 (b) one volume level in some parts of the piece, with sudden changes of volume between parts, (c) gradual increases or de-creases in volume during the piece; 8. Melodics, in the sense of a set selection of notes, based on the total sequence adopted, that is, scale: (a) pre-modal, (b) modal, (c) chromatic major, (d) chromatic minor, (e) chromatic major and minor, (f) whole-tone scale, (g) serial dodecaphonic struc-tures; 9. Leading Instrument Timbre (this category includes those in-struments, together with the human voice, that were actually se-lected by respondents, with the result that this category arose fol-lowing the collection and analysis of the pieces)~: (a) soprano, (b) mezzo-soprano, (c) alto, (d) tenor, (e) baritone, (f) bass, (g) soprano and tenor, (h) soprano and baritone, (i) choir, (l) vio-lin, (k) piano, (1) saxophone, (m) electric guitar, (n) synthe-sizer, (o) others. As a result of this analysis, each work of music was characterized in terms of the nine element set: Tempo, Changes in Tempo, Rhythm, Number of Melodic Themes, Sound Voluminosity, Meter, Sound Dynamics, Melodics, Leading Instrument Timbre. Procedure This research was conducted over a one-month period at the fol-lowing Polish universities: Wroclaw University, Wroclaw Technical University, Wroclaw School of Economics, Rzeszow Technical Uni-versity. The testing was undertaken in the lecture rooms of the above academic institutions, during morning hours, by daylight. Due to the time of year (fall) and the necessity of maintaining low noise levels in the rooms, all windows were closed during testing. The lectureroom walls were white in color. Testing was carried out in groups, with each group numbering about 20 people. Those who agreed to take part in this research were informed of its pur-pose and its progress. They completed the 16 PF Questionnaire and the Questionnaire of MusicaI Preferences. After collecting the completed questionnaires, analysis of these findings was begun. Using the 16 PF Questionnaire, the personality SCreating this category before musical analysis was impossible, due to the massive number of instruments appearing in the musical literature. Next, on the basis of the Questionnaire of Musical Preferences, a complete list of works of music, consisting of 117 pieces, was compiled (a listing of the pieces is shown in Appendix 1). The pieces, collected on CDs, were musi-cally analyzed, with each piece being described in terms of the nine-element set. Results A number of statistical methods were used in the verification of the hypotheses. For the determination of correlations between per-sonality traits and musical elements, two correlation coefficients were used. These are: Spearman's 7;, for ordinal variables (for mu-sic elements: Tempo, Changes in Tempo, Rhythm, Number of Melodic Themes, Sound Voluminosity) and Cramer's Vfor nomi-nal variables (for music elements: Meter, Sound Dynamics, Melod-ics, Leading Instrument Timbre). Next, F-test analysis of analysis of variance (ANOVA) was applied. The cz significance level was set at p < .05. The results of the statistical analysis are shown in Table 1. The discussion of the results is presented in a uniform format. First, the results for correlation coefficients are presented, next the variance analysis results. For those personality traits achieving sta-tistically significant values in the variance analysis, compilations of mean values are shown in chart form. The greatest number of relationships to musical elements was shown by Factor H. It achieved correlations with three elements: Tempo, Number of Melodic Themes and Meter. The q values in the case of Tempo and Number of Melodic Themes are positive, meaning that together with an increase in Factor H, preferences for musical pieces with faster tempo and a greater number of melodic themes increase. In the analysis of variance, Factor H also had relationships with three musical elements: Tempo, Number of Melodic Themes and Meter. In analyzing the compilation of mean Factor-H values for the element Tempo (see Figure 1), it is notice-able that people with the highest mean H are those choosing fast tempos in pieces of music. Further down the sequence with regard to mean H values are those choosing: Very Fast, Moderately Fast, Moderately Slow, Very Slow and Slow Tempos. The results achieved for these Factors are shown in Table 2. Factor O achieved correlations with seven musical elements: Tempo, Change in Tempo, Rhythm in relation to metrical basis, Number of Melodic Themes, Sound Voluminosity, Meter and Melody. However, in the analysis of variance, it showed a relation-ship to five musical elements: Tempo, Rhythm in relation to metri-cal basis, Number of Melodic Themes, Sound Voluminosity and Meter. Factor Q3 achieved correlations with four musical elements: Tempo, Number of Melodic Themes, Sound Voluminosity and Me-ter. However, in the analysis of variance, it showed a relationship to four musical elements: Tempo, Rhythm, Number of Melodic Themes and Sound Voluminosity. Factors C and Q4, in the corre-lation coefficients and the analysis of variance, showed a relation-ship with two musical elements: Tempo and Number of Melodic Themes. Factor E achieved correlations with Tempo and Number of Melodic Themes, while in the analysis of variance it showed a re-lationship only with the element Number of Melodic Themes. Fac-tor I also achieved correlations with Tempo and Number of Melodic Themes, while in the analysis of variance showing a rela-tionship with Tempo. The remaining factors contained in the 16PF questionnaire, such as Reasoning (B) and Privateness (N), did not display statisti-cally significant relationships with the musical elements isolated in this research. Discussion In the discussion of results, only those variables that achieved sta-tistically significant values, both in terms of their correlation coef-ficients and in the analysis of variance, are taken into considera-tion. Such a treatment enables an increase in confidence with regard to the relationships occurring between personality traits and musical elements, and also enables the at least partial elimina-tion of errors due to chance or else resulting from imperfections in statistical methods. In light of the above principle, the first hypothesis--that Factor A (Warmth) influences preferences regarding certain musical ele-ments-was not supported. The second hypothesis--that Factor F (Liveliness) influences preferences regarding certain musical ele-ments-was supported. Factor F achieved a relationship with the Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 233 Vol. XLII, No. 3, Fall 2005 musical element Number of Melodic Themes. People with higher F values (carefree, enthusiastic, spontaneous, energetic) choose works of music with higher numbers of melodic themes than those with lower F values (serious, quiet, reflective). The third hypothesis that Factor H (Social Boldness) influences preferences regarding certain musical elements--was supported. Factor H achieved rela-tionships with the following musical elements: Tempo, Number of Melodic Themes and Meter. The results show that people with higher H values (socially bold, outgoing, gregarious, adventure-some) prefer faster tempos, a greater number of melodic themes and also irregular meters (asymmetric or in free time) in pieces of music. Conversely, people with lower H values (shy, socially timid, threat-sensitive, easily embarrassed) prefer pieces with slower tem-pos, fewer melodic themes and more regular meters (duple, quadruple, triple rhythms). The fourth and fifth hypotheses that Factors Q2 (Self-Reliance) and M (Abstractedness) influence pref-erences regarding specific musical elements were not supported. The sixth hypothesis--that Factor Q1 (Openness to Change) in-fluences preferences regarding certain musical elements--was sup-ported. Factor Q1 achieved a relationship with the element Num-ber of Melodic Themes. The results show that people with higher Q1 values (open to change, experimenting, freethinking) prefer a greater number of melodic themes in works of music, compared to people with lower results on that scale (traditional, attached to the familiar, resistant to change). The seventh hypothesis--that Factor L (Vigilance) influences preferences regarding certain musical el-ements-was supported. Factor L also displayed a relationship with the element Number of Melodic Themes. People with higher L val-ues (vigilant, suspicious, distrustful) prefer musical pieces having a lower number of melodic themes than do people with higher val-ues on that scale (trusting, unsuspecting, forgiving, accepting). Further, analysis of the second-order factor of Extraversion showed that this factor demonstrated a relationship with two musical ele-ments: Tempo and Number of Melodic Themes. In works of music, extraverted people prefer faster tempos and greater numbers of melodic themes than do introverted people. Summing up, it should be emphasized that personality traits ex-ist that have effect on preferences regarding certain elements in works of music. The greatest influence has been shown in the case of Factor O (5 mtrsical elements), followed by Factors H and Q3 (3 mu- Downloaded from https://academic.oup.com/jmt/article-abstract/42/3/216/873070 by guest on 04 February 2020 234 Journal of Music Therapy sical elements), Factor C, Q4 and General Extraversion Factor (2 mu-sical elements), and Factors E, E 1, L, Q1 (1 musical element each). It is worth noting that the greatest effect on preferences regard-ing musical elements is shown by personality traits associated with temperament (Factors C, E, F, H, I, L, O, Q3, Q4, General Extraver-sion Factor) and by one dynamic trait (Factor Q1) (Cattell, 1950; Cattell et al., 1957). These results are in accordance with the studies mentioned at the beginning of this article. They show that some temperament traits (extraversion and introversion) have a signifi-cant effect on musical preferences (Burt, 1939; Klimas-Kuchtowa, 2000; McCown et al., 1997), and on the manner of music usage in everyday life (Furnham et al., 1999). Significance in musical preferences was demonstrated by those elements having stimulative value and the ability to regulate the need for stimulation. These elements are: Number of Melodic Themes, Tempo, Meter, Rhythm, Sound Voluminosity. However, the musical elements: Changes in Tempo, Sound Dynamics, Melodics, Leading Instrument Timbre, were not shown to be sig-nificant by this research. It may be that these elements differentiate musical preferences for a range of other personality traits, not cov-ered by this study. The above results admit the presumption that the works of music chosen by participants are combinations of stimuli that supply them with an appropriate dose of stimulation, allowing them to function in the environment. In conclusion, it should be emphasized that the findings of this study have practical application in all techniques and methods em-ploying music for the therapeutic purposes. It is also possible to draw some important conclusions from the above research: 1. In choosing music for therapeutic purposes, one should take into account individual differences connected with tempera-ment traits, and most particularly with the need for stimulation. Ignoring such differences could have contrary effects, unin-tended by the therapist. Exceeding the optimal dose for musical stimulation or lack thereof can produce symptoms of stress. Mu-sic with a high stimulative value, as preferred by extraverts, may lead to stress in introverts. On the other hand, music with low stimulative value, as preferred by introverts, may be a source of stress for extraverts. 2. Based on the above, one should not use the same relaxing or energizing music on both groups: extraverts and introverts. Method Participants Randomly chosen students (N--- 145) in higher education in Poland participated in this study.

Material The 16 PF Questionnaire (Cattell et al., 1957; Russel & Karol, 1993) in the Polish adaptation by Choynowski (Nowakowska, 1970) was used in this research, as well as the Questionnaire of Musical Pref-erences (created by the author for the purposes of this research).

The analysis of mean values for Factor F (see Figure 4) and Factor Q1 (see Figure 5) indicates that people characterized by a higher mean F and Q1 choose pieces with a high number of melodic themes, while conversely people with lower mean F and Q1 choose pieces with a low number of melodic themes.

The analysis of mean values for Factor F (see Figure 4) and Factor Q1 (see Figure 5) indicates that people characterized by a higher mean F and Q1 choose pieces with a high number of melodic themes, while conversely people with lower mean F and Q1 choose pieces with a low number of melodic themes.

In contrast, the analysis of mean Factor-L values (see Figure 6) indicates that people characterized by higher mean L values choose musical pieces with low numbers of melodic themes, while those characterized by lower mean Factor-L values tend to choose musical pieces with a high number of melodic themes.

However, in the analysis of variance, it showed a relation-ship to five musical elements: Tempo, Rhythm in relation to metri-cal basis, Number of Melodic Themes, Sound Voluminosity and Meter.

Discussion In the discussion of results, only those variables that achieved sta-tistically significant values, both in terms of their correlation coef-ficients and in the analysis of variance, are taken into considera-tion.
The second hypothesis--that Factor F (Liveliness) influences preferences regarding certain musical ele-ments-was supported.
People with higher F values (carefree, enthusiastic, spontaneous, energetic) choose works of music with higher numbers of melodic themes than those with lower F values (serious, quiet, reflective).

Many studies show that music preferred by the client is comparable in its effectiveness to that chosen by the thera-pist, with regard to reduction of anxiety (Iwanaga & Moroki, 1999; Thaut & Davis, 1999).
